Validation in cyberinterventions: an introduction to this themed issue

  • Anna Spagnolli1 &
  • Cheryl Campanella Bracken2 

Virtual Reality volume 18, pages1–4(2014)Cite this article

  • 250 Accesses

  • 1 Citations

  • Metrics details

Introduction

The number of virtual reality applications and digital environments that support the promotion of personal and social change is incredibly rich and incessantly increasing. These applications can be found in very different, often unrelated domains; typical examples might be computerised programs to support smoking cessation; widgets to monitor household energy consumption; serious games to increase sensitivity towards political or humanitarian issues; and mobile applications to plan everyday commutes to work to avoid contributing to traffic jams. Also the platform supporting these and similar interventions varies considerably, ranging from immersive virtual worlds, to stand-alone driving simulators, to mobile applications and many others. Nevertheless, despite this heterogeneity of application domains and technological platforms, technologically mediated interventions share several common issues. Examining common issues allows the extension of reflections and solutions to application domains not mature yet, as well as to encourage standard terminology and indices to allow comparisons and meta-analyses, which is unfortunately not often the case even within the same application domain (see for telemedicine interventions, Young 2012). Here, we would like to characterise some of these common issues, focusing on one of them in particular, i.e. validation.

Cyberinterventions

When talking about of technologically mediated interventions (or ‘cyberinterventions’ for brevity), we have several applications in mind. Eco-feedback technologies, where users are equipped with digital tools and sensors to monitor their use of energy resources and then increase their awareness of the environmental consequences of each single consumption act. Cybertherapy, where a digital environment permits the delivery of a therapeutic treatment and often also provides information to measure and evaluate the intensity of some symptoms. Serious games improving the drivers’ ability to detect in advance the potential risk involved in certain traffic situations and driving behaviours. And many others. What these different interventions have in common is that they are conscious attempts at modifying people’s actions, attitudes and habits with a protocol that is primarily supported by an interactive digital environment.

Technologically mediated interventions represent a form of persuasive technology (PT), i.e. of technology designed to form, alert or reinforce attitudes, behaviours or an act of complying (Fogg 2003; Oinas-Kukkonen 2010). What distinguishes them from other PTs is that: (a) the ultimate goal of the intervention is the users’ or society's wellness, such as psychological well-being, environmental protection, and civilised behaviours and not other—legitimate—ones, such as profit or entertainment; (b) technology is not necessarily conceived as a stand-alone method for intervention but may be part of a larger protocol; this is the case for example of training sessions to increase safety driving, which can be included in a high school syllabus and facilitated by the presence of a teacher; and (c) the intervention can exploit technology that was not necessarily designed to deliver the intervention in the first place, but is re-used later to that purpose.

The increasing recourse to employ digital environments to deliver an intervention is due to several motivations. Digital, interactive technology can improve fidelity in the administration of the protocol even with high number of users by implementing phases and instructions for the intervention in the computer application. Technology can enable tailoring of the intervention by automatically adapting it to specific usage and user profiles. Technology can offer the possibility to design situations that would be too dangerous, expensive or even impossible to be experienced in the real physical environment. Finally, technology allows researchers and/or clinicians the ability to record usage data that help to monitor the progress and success of the intervention itself. Of course, the use of technology at the same time emphasises some possible risks of an intervention.

One risk is coercion or deception by embedding tricks in the computer interface (such as those collected by Harri Brignul, Marc Miquel and Jeremy Rosenberg in their ‘dark patterns’ website, http://darkpatterns.org/). Applying general codes of conduct for professionals working with technologies (e.g. IEEE and ACM) and working for the wellness of human beings (e.g. American Psychological Association and British Psychological Association) helps to ensure the adoption of ethically acceptable methods. In addition, some specific ethical guidelines for technologically mediated interventions have been highlighted. They include ensuring that participation is agreed upon explicitly Smids (2012), that the intervention material is comprehensible to the recipient and that the intervention process aims at ending the treatment to leave the recipient able to take care of him/herself Spahn (2012). Furthermore, the way in which the user is represented must be respectful; this means allowing plurality and choice within the intervention Spahn (2012) and protecting personal or sensitive data processed and potentially stored in the device. This last aspect is regulated at the governmental level in several countries; provisions include identifying risks and possible solutions and implementing recommendations Wright (2013).

Another risk is an oversimplification in the way in which the user is represented in the intervention program. This has been recently the subject of theoretical debate in the area of computer applications for sustainable behaviour. The users’ target behaviour is often represented with measures and indices that carry some positive or negative evaluation instrumental to motivate change. Rhetorically, these measures risk being presented or perceived as non-controversial and objective. Instead, it is important that these indices, although resulting from automatic measurements, are presented as one among several possible perspectives on the users’ behaviour Brynjarsdóttir et al. (2012). Also, authors suggest that even though the individual is the default target of an intervention, this might not be most appropriate solution: behaviours might result from social processes and decisions located within larger social units than the individual, for instance, the family or the household Brynjarsdóttir et al. (2012). It is then recommended to take care in identifying the proper unit of action responsible for the specific class of behaviour targeted by the intervention and to balance procedural standardization with sensitivity to the context in which the intervention takes place.

Validation

Any effort to design an effective ethical and appropriate intervention needs to be accompanied by a pretest proving that the intervention is actually able to achieve its intended goals. Validating is not the same as evaluating. While evaluation might regard any aspect of the intervention including its theoretical foundations, its piloting and its implementation Craig et al. (2008); validation refers more narrowly to the extent to which the intervention achieves its intended goals and sub-goals (Carmines and Zeller 1979). Therefore, validation consists of making explicit the goals of the intervention, defining the indices to measure the achievement of these goals and carrying out the measurement with a proper procedure and sample.

As is explained by Spagnolli, Bracken and Orso in this issue, validation of interventions ‘can regard first of all the efficacy of their design and is called internal validity (…). Two specific forms of internal validity are often identified, criterion and content validity: the former shows that a valid criterion correlates with the outcomes of the object of validation in the present or in the future (concurrent or predictive validity); the latter ensures that the object of validation properly and comprehensively represents the domain it intends to cover. In addition to internal validity, a measurement tool/experiment/treatment can be validated by construct validity, namely by establishing the relation on a theoretical basis between the outcomes of the object of validation and other concept(s) that can be measured. Finally, the measurement tool/experiment/treatment can be validated externally, for their generalizability across persons, times and settings’. They also add that validation includes feasibility assessment (e.g. its costs, acceptability, training of administering personnel and infrastructure) and contextualisation to the target’s characteristics, culture and preferences.

Specific to technologically mediated intervention is the need to validate the digital environment, proving that it is suitable to the intervention and able to support the appropriate type of user experience. One way to validate the environment is to test its usability under the assumption that in order to be effective the environment needs first to be usable. This is the case for Schwebel, McClure and Severson in this issue; they validate an Internet-based virtual environment to teach children about pedestrian safety—namely to instruct children on how to safely cross a virtual street. The authors stated that pedestrian accidents are the leading cause of death for children in the United States; their system has the added value of being technically light-weighted and financially more affordable than common VR traffic trainings. In their case, evaluating usability was crucial since the environment was meant to be used by children without the adult’s support. The authors measured the self-reported ease of use of the system through structured interviews with the young users and the frequency of help requests during the interaction with the system, finding encouraging results. Another purpose with which the virtual environment of a cyberintervention is validated is by ensuring that it facilitates the proper user experience, namely that it triggers the expected dimensions of the user experience conditional to the intervention efficacy. Spagnolli, Campanella Bracken and Orso treat this aspect with respect to cyberinterventions for psychological disorders (cybertherapy), where one crucial aspect of the digital experience is the sense of being present in the digital environment. This sense of presence is a psychological dimension that might be especially important when the digital experience represent part of a psychological treatment. Their review shows in which ways this is actually the case both conceptually and empirically and then how the concept of presence serves validation. Their review presents a series of questions to guide future research and calls for a more explicit elaboration of the dimensions of presence relevant to the treatment while selecting the measurement tool.

While cyberinterventions state their added value compared with traditional intervention modalities, they also establish a connection with them in several ways, most commonly by defining their discriminant or criterion validity. Renaud, Trottier, Rouleau, Goyette, Saumur, Soukhalfi and Bouchard address a sensitive and challenging issue—measuring sexually deviant responses. Their measurement apparatus can serve forensic assessment as well as self-regulation programs for sexual offenders, especially pedophiles, which is a global concern and the human and financial costs are enormous. While the assessment of pedophiles is extremely challenging and some methods might be questionable, this paper examines an immersive virtual reality environment that measures penile plethysmography using computer-generated characters as triggers. The validation of this assessment technique is based on its ability to discriminate between deviant versus non-deviant adult males and on comparing its accuracy in classifying an individual with the accuracy of traditional auditory material. Authors demonstrate that their VR environment has potential in forensic assessment of sexual deviance. Similarly, Tremblay, Chebbi, Bouchard, Cimon-Lambert and Carmichael test a hapto-visual virtual reality solution for assessing visual-motor skills, which can be used within a training program for people with learning disabilities and which they found was never tested against a control group. They measured the discriminant ability of their technique, by comparing the performance with the VR tool of people with and without learning disabilities. They also administered a paper and pencil test of visual-motor skills called Bender-Gestalt as a validation criterion, but it did not discriminate between the two groups used in the study. Therefore, the question they ask is what kind of ability was measured by their tool, one that is included in learning disorders but does not overlap with the kind of visual—more skills measured by the Bender-Gestalt. This study shows the limits of the conclusions that can be drawn from discriminant validation alone. Gutiérrez-Maldonado, Rus-Calafell and González intend to use cyberintervention to assist patients with schizophrenia to improve their ability to read and interpret facial expressions of emotion. Instead of using photographs, their system uses virtual faces based on the Facial Action Coding System (FACS), in order to provide dynamic information commonly available in real faces and useful to recognise emotions. The study was meant to validate virtual faces ability to represent recognisable emotions. Users’ performance (accuracy of recognition and response time) with their stimuli was compared with performance at the Penn Emotion Recognition Test, which is—in their word—‘one of the most commonly used task of assessing facial emotion recognition deficits in people suffering from schizophrenia’. In doing so, they also followed the recommendation from the Ethics Committee of the Adult Mental Health Unit (AMHU) of Igualada (the mental health unit involved in the whole research project), according to which virtual environments and virtual characters must be tested in a non-clinical population before establishing the virtual intervention in the clinical setting.

Of course, the measures used to validate the interventions must be themselves valid measures, namely related with the phenomenon they are meant to capture. This is why many authors used traditional, established measures, although cyberinterventions would have the added value of logging the users’ conduct and state, which makes the set of indices available for validation much richer and reliable than in traditional kinds of intervention. Serino, Triberti, Vallani, Cipresso, Gaggioli and Riva in their review of cyberinterventions for stress disorders based on stress inoculation training (SIT) or Cyber-SIT, examined the measures used to validate the treatment. They show that outcome measures can consist of self-reported measures from target users about their psychological state, of the collection of behavioural or psychophysiological indices of their psychological state or measuring variables that are theoretically related to the target psychological state. Of these, only a few are automatically collected by the system, which seems like a missed opportunity in technologically mediated interventions.

Conclusions

Although most studies in this collection relate to one specific area of cyberintervention, e.g. interventions of psychological disorders, the issues raised extend to other areas. In particular, validating the mediated environment becomes an essential component of validating the overall intervention. Also, identifying the dimensions of the user experience that are crucial to the effectiveness of the intervention is a necessary precondition to a well-structured validation. Finally, although the recourse to established intervention techniques or assessment tools allows comparison with other studies, it should not prevent designers to take advantage of the new opportunities to create measures opened up by the use of an information system to support the intervention.

We would like to thank the authors who contributed to this theme issue—especially for writing and reviewing the submissions. Their effort allowed us to offer a view of the current validation endeavours in the area of technologically mediated interventions. Hopefully, the discussion with different areas of technologically mediated interventions will thrive in the next years.

We dedicate this theme issue to the memory of Dr. Paul Skalski.
